raw_text:
Gallery unveils interactive tree
 
 A Christmas tree that can receive text messages has been unveiled at London's Tate Britain art gallery.
 
 The spruce has an antenna which can receive Bluetooth texts sent by visitors to the Tate. The messages will be "unwrapped" by sculptor Richard Wentworth, who is responsible for decorating the tree with broken plates and light bulbs. It is the 17th year that the gallery has invited an artist to dress their Christmas tree. Artists who have decorated the Tate tree in previous years include Tracey Emin in 2002.
 
 The plain green Norway spruce is displayed in the gallery's foyer. Its light bulb adornments are dimmed, ordinary domestic ones joined together with string. The plates decorating the branches will be auctioned off for the children's charity ArtWorks. Wentworth worked as an assistant to sculptor Henry Moore in the late 1960s. His reputation as a sculptor grew in the 1980s, while he has been one of the most influential teachers during the last two decades. Wentworth is also known for his photography of mundane, everyday subjects such as a cigarette packet jammed under the wonky leg of a table.
llama3.2:1b: A Christmas tree at London's Tate Britain art gallery has been unveiled with an interactive feature that allows it to receive text messages from visitors. The tree uses Bluetooth technology and can display unwrapped messages by sculptor Richard Wentworth, who is responsible for decorating the tree.
llama3.2:3b: A Christmas tree with an antenna that receives Bluetooth texts has been unveiled at London's Tate Britain gallery. The tree, decorated by sculptor Richard Wentworth, will receive messages from visitors and be "unwrapped" over time. It is displayed in the gallery's foyer as part of the gallery's 17th annual tradition of inviting an artist to decorate a Christmas tree.
gemma2:2b: A decorated Christmas tree at London's Tate Britain can receive text messages from visitors.  Sculptor Richard Wentworth will "unveil" these texts by decorating the tree with broken plates and light bulbs. The tree is part of an annual tradition where artists decorate the gallery's tree.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Tate Britain unveils Christmas tree with text messages, featuring Richard Wentworth as artist responsible for decorating the tree. The spruce tree, which has a built-in antenna, is displayed in Tate's foyer and features dimmed light bulb decorations along with ordinary domestic ones joined together with string. The plates decorating the branches will be auctioned off at ArtWorks.
qwen2.5:1.5b: A Christmas tree at Tate Britain can receive Bluetooth texts and display them through light bulbs and plates; it's part of an annual tradition since 1954 featuring previous artists including Tracey Emin.
qwen2.5:3b: A Christmas tree at London's Tate Britain art gallery can receive text messages via an antenna on its branches. Sculptor Richard Wentworth will unwrap Bluetooth texts sent by visitors with decorations including dim light bulbs and broken plates, which are to be auctioned for charity. This 17th year the gallery invites an artist to decorate their Christmas tree; previous decorators include Tracey Emin in 2002. The plain green Norway spruce has ordinary domestic light bulbs stringed together and is adorned with plates that will be sold for children's charity ArtWorks. Wentworth, who worked as Henry Moore's assistant in the late 1960s and taught art since the past two decades, also creates photography of everyday subjects.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text about a new interactive Christmas tree in London's Tate Britain gallery. Let me read through it carefully.

So, first, the Gallery has unveiled an interactive tree. It uses text messages that visitors can send using Bluetooth. The sculptor Richard Wentworth will decode and unwrap them as he usual method, placing broken plates and bulbs on each branch. It's been running for 17 years and was hosted by artist Tracey Emin in 2002. There are prizes from children's charity ArtWorks, which gets the plate decorations.

I should focus on key points: the tree is spruce, uses Bluetooth, viewers can send messages via text on their phones or devices. It's been running for a long time, hosted by Emin, and features broken items that are sold. I need to make sure all these details are included in the summary concisely without any extra explanations.
</think>

The Tate Britain gallery has unveiled an interactive Christmas tree, a spruce with an antenna designed to receive text messages via Bluetooth. Viewers can decode and unwrap the messages as sculptor Richard Wentworth deciphers them while placing broken plates and bulbs on each branch. This 17-year program was hosted by artist Tracey Emin in 2002, with prize money from ArtWorks for the sold items.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Taté Britain Art Gallery has unveiled an interactive Christmas tree that can receive text messages sent by visitors. The tree features decorations made from broken plates, light bulbs, and ordinary household items, including string. The plain green Norway spruce is displayed in the gallery's foyer, with its lights dimmed and other decorations joined together with string. Artist Richard Wentworth created the replication of a sculptor's process while working under Moore's tutelage in the late 1960s, while he has also produced photographs depicting everyday subjects such as cigarette packets jammed under legs. The tree will be auctioned off for children's charity ArtWorks by Wentworth himself, who also teaches at the Tate in the past two decades.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The gallery unveiled an interactive Christmas tree at London's Tate Britain art gallery that can receive text messages from visitors. The tree features an antenna that can detect Bluetooth signals sent by people to the tree, allowing them to send messages through the tree. Richard Wentworth, who is responsible for decorating the tree with broken plates and light bulbs, decided to include a special feature this year by displaying his previous Christmas trees in the gallery's foyer. The tree's artificial lights are dimmed and ordinary items like string decorations will be auctioned off for children's charity ArtWorks.

The plain green Norway spruce's light bulb decorations are dimmed, and the plates decorating its branches will be auctioned off for ArtWorks children's charity. Wentworth is known as a sculptor, teacher, and photographer of everyday subjects.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Tate Britain's annual Christmas tree, decorated by sculptor Richard Wentworth, now features an interactive element: it can receive Bluetooth-sent text messages from visitors. The 17th artist to adorn this Norway spruce in the gallery's foyer, Wentworth incorporates broken plates and light bulbs into his design. Previous notable decorators include Tracey Emin. A portion of the decorations will be auctioned for children's charity ArtWorks. Wentworth, an assistant to Henry Moore and a renowned sculptor, teacher, and photographer known for capturing mundane, everyday scenes, created this interactive tree.

Visitors can send Bluetooth texts to the tree, which will be "unwrapped" by sculptor Richard Wentworth, who decorated it with broken plates and dimmed light bulbs. Wentworth, a former assistant to Henry Moore, gained recognition in the 1980s and is known for his photography of everyday objects.
